description: Tried to see them last year climbing the Filbert steps up to Coit tower, but couldn't locate them. I do a lot of walking around Embarcadero and still never managed to run into them-until today. I heard their screeching frmo a far and saw them flying to the Sue Bierman Park so I followed and was able to snap a few pictures. Sooo cute, with very very cheerful screeching.
author: Zaynub N.

description:
Climb to Coit Tower, take a seat on a bench under the hill's leafy greenness, and listen carefully for the cheerful screeching of Telegraph Hill's parrots. They fly in flocks--watch for pointy wings and straight tails.

They're not always here, but if you're patient, you're usually rewarded with a glimpse of their cherry-red heads. 
On a recent trip to San Francisco, I did just that, and was able to spend many long minutes watching a pair of parrots guarding a nest just overhead.
author: Patti I.

description: I often record episodes of my podcast in the park and they make frequent cameos that always get unique reactions from first time listeners and guests.
author: Kevin G.

description: Remember them at Telegraph Hill and also there is a flock up above Dolores Park in large Cypress near 615 Sanchez. Very  loud! Nice to have them around!
author: B H.

description:
Storytime. Hiked around Cpit Tower, Filbert Steps, and Greenwich steps.. no parrots. Got to base of Greenwich steps (the brick ones on east side of Coit Tower), unlock car to drive home sad, and BAM!! 25 green wild parrots race by overhead, squawking their Sunday blues away.

So yeah pretty dope. Guess they show up when you least expect them.
author: Justin W.

description: So cool to have parrots in San francisco. Went up there today and there was a whole flock. They are so cool and totally worth it to see.
author: Ford W.

description:
My last two visits to SF have resulted in seeing or hearing the conures in the palms across from the ferry building, which seems to be one of their hangout spots. It always astounds me knowing that wild parrots thrive in such a bustling city. As a bird enthusiast, I think it adds to the charm of SF! Although I'm sure the conures' human neighbors aren't too thrilled with all the screeching and squawking... 

Anyway, if you're a birdwatcher visiting the area, observing the flock is a must!!
author: Sierra R.

description: They are amazing.We did not see them at Telegraph Hill but on two trees across from the Ferry Building.
author: Phuong M.

description: We saw 2 of the Parrots yesterday in the palm trees across the street from the Ferry Building.  We followed the squawking.
author: Ann C.

description:
Wild parrots. In San Francisco. Cackling all day long.

Side note, they often hang out in Sue Bierman park in the evenings, so if you don't find them on Telegraph Hill, check the trees across from the Ferry Building.
author: Nick K.

description:
Dang! These guys are loud! (But adorable) 

First of all, this neat group of animals have a documentary featuring them:  http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0424565/   and a really cool website discussing their existence: http://www.markbittner.net/parrot_pages/wildparrots.html (by the author of a book bearing their name)

Scoping out the parrots is one of my favorite free hobbies in San Francisco (free hobbies are few and far between in SF - hahaha!) The best way to hear and see them is in Sue Bierman Park, which is just west of the Ferry Building or on Telegraph Hill in and among the trees along the Greenwich and Filbert Steps.  I find that they are loudest in the afternoons until sunset.
author: Andrea H.

description:
I'll never forget the first time I saw The Parrots of Telegraph Hill. Was walking from the Ferry Building to the FiDi and saw the flock fly overhead. 

"No way did I just see that. Parrots? Really." 

Yes, they're a real thing in San Francisco. Of course, in a city that smells like weed, poop/pee and the ocean, where nudies run free (well, not so much anymore) and everyone has their crazy MUNI story, there's gotta be parrots. 

Apparently urban parrots aren't unique to San Francisco, but let's not focus on that right now. Instead, let's pay homage to these beautiful birds! Def watch the documentary to learn more.

You'll hear them before you see them, for sure. Their squawking is most definitely unique. Now that I know the noise, have been able to spot them from afar near the Palace of Fine Arts, near Telegraph Hill and SoMa. 

Residents of the Telegraph Hill neighborhood might consider them a nuisance (yes, they are pretty loud), but damn it, they're so beautiful and special to San Francisco. I hope they live long and prosper in this crazy city we call home.
author: Abby S.

description: I've been taking walks along The Embarcadero near the Ferry Bldg and see these conure birds happily flying together from one tall tree to another. They have a distinct sound and are loud in the morning. I personally have never seen these wild birds fly near ground, they always seem to stay high above somewhere. I know these birds can be very friendly because I used to own a Sun Conure and Green Cheek conure that I bought from pet stores at over $400 each. These birds demand your attention and are quite affectionate. I was surprised to see pictures from this site of people feeding these birds because I didn't think they ever go to ground level. I always wonder what these birds eat in the wild. When I had them as pets, they loved eating mixed nuts including raw nuts in the shell. I don't keep birds as pets anymore, but it puts a smile on my face when I see these birds flying around san francisco. Casey.
author: Casey C.

description: I find it odd that you can leave a review for a bunch of wild parrots but on the other hand, I'm glad you can. I love these birds. I saw the documentary 15 years ago. When you see them in person it's pretty interesting. They look like pets, in fact, I heard people going "why are all those birds green?" As if it was a bunch of green pigeons flying around. They hang on trees and move around and it's great to watch, a definite unique San Francisco attraction.
author: Chimpy L.

description: One of the few things that I miss about working in San Francisco.  Worth the walk to the top of the stairs to Coit Tower.
author: Abigail J. M. M.

description:
One of the things I miss most about living in SF are the parrots -- when I lived in SF, I could regularly see the flocks of parrots flying around from one preferred spot to another.  Visiting them on Telegraph Hill was always a lot of fun - the birds are just gorgeous.  It's so much fun seeing them flying through downtown SF, their distinctive calls and colors livening up the Financial District.

If you haven't seen the documentary - I highly recommend "The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill" -- it's just another facet of what makes San Francisco so unique and interesting.
author: Jenn C.

description: I ran into these awesome birds quite by accident while I was exploring the city. I am so happy to see that other people appreciate them as well.
author: Ananassa D.

description: Have you even seen San Diego parrots? Not saying these guys are the worst, but I've had my latte ruined by much better.
author: Loren G.

description:
What a silly thing to write a review for. Do you think they'll read it?
Love hearing these little buggers in the AM. It's like I'm in nature, without being in nature.
author: Melissa R.

description:
It's an amazing sight to see this flock of squawking, colorful parrots flying in unison through the Financial District skyscrapers. A part of me forgets they live here too, so they sort of catch me off guard every time. 

I always see them in the park behind Embarcadero 3, but they make their rounds between FiDi and Telegraph Hill. If you're quiet and gentle enough, they might even take food from your hand.

My family and I used to breed and handraise small parrots (like these) during my childhood, so the Parrots of Telegraph Hill have a special place in my heart.
author: Mariela D.

description:
These damn birds aren't getting 5 stars from me, yet! I have made two pain-in-the-ass, and thighs jaunts up these damn steps to get a glimpse. Not even pooped on by these fine-feathered friends, either... and I've only seen one so far! Yep, one brave parrot (apparently on the look-out for weirdos).

If you are of sound mind and like to exercise indoors, I suggest you walk down the steps FROM Coit. But, if you want to get your exercise on, pack in a week's worth of bootie and thigh work in one outing and trott up the steps TO Coit. Either way, you should be able to see these parrots. Or so I've been told.

Damn, I'm starting to feel like Damien from "The Omen" when he made all of the animals go ape-shit on family car during a drive-thru safari-like outing. I swear they are hiding from me... I heard them, but they're afraid of me! C'mon I'm such a great poop-target! The seagulls have never had a problem dropping a load on me!
author: Kara B.

description:
If I was going off of seeing these birds once, I'd give it 5 stars. My ex's relative lived right above the park where many of these birds hung out and wow! These birds are ridiculously noisy! Squawk, squawk, squawk! They just don't quit. 

If you haven't had the chance to see them, do. it's a one time thing, then I was over it once I realized just how noisy they are.

If you don't live in San Fran and don't have the chance to come see them, I suggest watching the documentary "The Parrots of Telegraph Hill" on Netflix. It's almost better than seeing them live.
author: Rachel S.

description:
You can hear their distinctive squawking overhead from many points in the city.

They tend to fly around in small flocks of 3 to a dozen birds.  I think they prefer high vantage points, as I frequently see them fly overhead at UCSF on Parnassus, heading in the direction of Mt Sutro.
author: Gopal R.

description:
A flock of about 50 or so flew over me today, very awesome!

It was around Broadway & Gough
author: J. G.

description:
Oh San Francisco
Why do I love thee
Is it because you have naked old men during Bay to Breakers
Is it because you have the annual naked cycling event?
Is it because the Mission smells of weed?
Is it because on a sunny day, the sight of the glorious red Golden Gate Bridge takes my breath away?
Or is it because you have the red & green South American parrots, the Parrots of Telegraph Hill?
Flying up across downtown
Squaking like they had no neighbors
Only in San Francisco
This is why I love thee
author: Katie T.

description: My wife and I saw a flock (5 to 7 birds) flying around Coit Tower on our last visit to San Francisco in September 2013.  I thought I was mistaken at first but they reappeared a few minutes later.  What a delightful surprise!
author: Lenny T.

description: My friends and I stumbled across these parrots completely by accident--but what a find! There's dozens of them and they're so beautiful! They always fly in a gorgeous green flock and you can hear them squawking from half a mile away. They seem to love going from the tall trees to the shorter blossoming trees, which is where you'll have the most luck being able to get up close to them.
author: Josephine L.

description: My wife and I watched a documentary about these parrots and then went on the walk down the hill from Coit Tower. We enjoyed the walk down the long staircase past the homes on this hill, and the noisiness of the parrots made us laugh. It was beautiful to see them flying around. There's also a very nice view as you're walking down the steps.
author: Zander K.

description: From the yelp photos, I thought the parrots would be just lounging about on Telegraph Hill but once we got there they were no where to be found:-(
author: Oulie T.

description: 5 Beaks up for the wild parrots of Telegraph Hill. If you haven't seen the movie by the same name, look for it on Netflix. Very worthwhile rental. Then, come see them flock and squawk IRL. Birds of a feather squawk together. You will be a fan.
author: Paul B.

description:
Parrots live in SF!?! Yes, it's true.
Climb the Filbert Steps to Telegraph Hill instead of taking the bus. You'll hopefully see the parrots! 

Birds, I'd like you a LOT more if you'd keep your squawking to a minimum in the AM hours.
author: Sara P.

description:
OMG... I'm a total bird person and have 4 feathered babies... I saw the movie and totally loved these spunky conures. Unfortunately I feel really bad for the people who have to live constantly around them. When Pineapple-Joey Pied Pie (my adorable cockatiel) gets into the mood of singing and screaming repeatedly a very off key version of Pirates of the Carribbean, it's enough for me to go bonkers. I can't imagine what it's like when these parrots go into screaming/singing mode.

Needless to say, it's still super cute to watch when they fly around. For a non-resident of Telegraph Hill... I think they're totally awesome~!
author: Vicky L.

description: They are regular visitors to our bird feeder. In fact, as I am typing this, I can see them perching on the pine tree outside my window. I just can't get over this. We are doubly diligent about keeping the feeder full now.
author: Anne W.

description: Just saw a large flock last night near Julius Castle on Telegraph Hill, squawking and having tons of fun frolicking in the trees. It was a wonderful time. Made my day!
author: J. A.

description: Absolute magic. I climbed the filbert steps from the bottom street level and it was so worth it. Driving up just doesn't have the same effect. Meeting these little guys in the trees above is absolutely worth every drop of sweat and potential leg cramp. Lol
author: Kristen J.

description:
** UPDATE **
Apparently the guy who originally started feeding the parrots (and  a small band of supporters) thinks it's an unnatural travesty to feed them since it's not just him doing it anymore. Ducks are just fine, but not the parrots. The board of supes has illegalized the practice of feeding the parrots. Most of the time, I love living in such a liberal city. This is not one of them. There was nothing wrong with humans interacting with these amazing birds and feeding them. Score one for the "protectors of wild animals."

** ORIGINAL REVIEW **
It's kinda like an Alfred Hitchcock movie, except the birds are pretty and they're nice to you instead. I've never had so much fun with birds crawling all over me. It's really a LOT of fun, a great thing to bring out-of-town friends to see. The park fills up with them a little while before sunset. They all congregate there to go to sleep at night. 

If you want them to swarm you, here's what you do:
1) Get two forks from your kitchen drawer. 
2) Buy a few apples and cut them in half.
3) Go to the park at the corner of Clay and Drumm at about an hour before sunset.
4) Stab a half apple at a time onto each fork and pretend you're a scarecrow.

This is one of those things that makes you glad to be an SF resident. I've been to feed the parrots about 5 or 6 times now, and can't get enough of them. It's also a really good workout. Your arms will get pretty tired holding up all the parrots after five minutes or so. Oh, also, you'll want to wear a hoody or be sure not to let one of them get bored if it's on your shoulder. They like to nibble, the way you might imagine an animal with a sharp vise for a mouth might nibble. If they don't have food to chew on, then ears will do. It's not out of malice, more curiosity than anything. Just the same, it hurts.

If you're entertaining kids or adults, this is an experience they'll remember. I'll add a few pix to my profile for this one.
author: Mike W.

description: Uniquely San Francisco.  Years ago we went to the theater at the Embarcadero to see the Oscar -nominated documentary, The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill.  In the Park adjacent to the shopping center, there we found the parrots just after viewing the documentary.  We were told they usually visit the same spots at the same time every day.
author: Ottis M.

description: 50 of them - a colonizing off-shoot, just settled on a big pine tree over on Corbett Avenue near the Castro. First time I have seen them settle on a tree over here. We have had small groups fly over, squawking, from time to time.
author: Vera N.

description:
Saw the movie and then we had to come see for ourselves.  I'd suggest watching it first - it's on Netflix  "The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)". 

Start at Coit Tower - take the tour - you'll like it if you like art - and then afterwards take a walk down the east stairways (on the Bay Bridge side). 

1/2 of the way down there's a landing in the walkway - there's some signage about the birds - anyway - look up and listen  I've been there three times and seen them each time.  

Way cool!
author: Paul C.

description:
While climbing up the endless yet beautiful stairs I heard them. Then I saw them flying over head. I was more concerned with catching my breath than anything else though.

When some European tourists asked if my friend and I had seem the parrots I said no even though I had. I don't know why I lied to them.  Nor did I know that this was in fact a local attraction. I'm used to seeing random cockatiels, parakeets, etc flying around L.A. in small groups that I didn't find it odd to see them in S.F. too.

I guess if I'd have seen them up close eating it'd have been neat. Next time I'll appreciate them rather than brushing them off.
author: Laura L.

description:
If you haven't seen the movie, do so.  Make sure you watch the special feature that includes the long interview with the woman who used to live on Lombard Street.  She's funny, and she reminds me of my cousin.

The birds themselves are wonderful.  There's too much sadness in this city, which is why I love these guys so much.
author: John S.

description: We used to love feeding the parrots at the small park near Embarcadaro. Then that was stopped by the city. Later we found them at the Union St Stairs along Calhoun Terrace, then the bird feeder was gone. We used to spot them often on both Filbert St stairs as well as the Greenwich St stairs (when the loquat blooms with fruit), but nowadays it's abit tougher to find them here.
author: Peter L.

description:
Took a nice walk late this afternoon from North Beach to Coit Tower.  Realized it was late afternoon and that the parrots would probably be at happy hour at the Embarcadero, but wanted the exercise and was hoping for the best.  As I arrived at one of my usual lucky parrot spots, I was rewarded with a couple nice fly-overs.  There was a bunch of them flying over-head and in formation following the leader.  Saw them up close and it was quite a sight to behold with their cute little red (cherry) heads and their little wings flapping furiously as they went by.  Against the vistas of the bay, it was almost magical and sooooo San Francisco.  As always, it made me really happy and totally brightened my day.

Lastly, I have to add...with stairs like these...who needs a Stairmaster? :)
author: Roy N.

description:
I used to live on Powell below Washington Square Park, and I would hear more parrots than I saw. The noisy buggers fly fast, gossiping the whole way about Shiela's tail feathers, or George's pushy nephew, or where to score the best palm berries this week. Yap yap yap squawk squawk - Poof! They are gone and the streets are silent. 

They are pretty birds and I hope the local Peregrine Falcon gets to eat a couple for dinner one day.
author: Virginia V.

description:
After watching the Mark Bittner Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill documentary, I knew finding these charming cherry-headed conures would be at the top of my travel agenda. My boss, an avid birder and North Beach expert, told me they like to hang out at the bottom of Lombard Street--exactly where I located them my first day in the city. 

"Ooo!" I whipped my head around when I heard their soothing sounds, which I find impossible to describe in writing. A cross between squawking, honking, singing and cooing, their calls are surprisingly melodious. 

A herd of tourists already had gathered beneath the power line on which the parrots perched, mostly huddled in pairs. 

"Wa-wa-wa-wa-wa!" they called, whooshing into a tree across the street. Buoying with the tree limbs, they fed on something within the leaves. The parrots seemed to smile and enjoy the attention, filling me with unexpected joy. 

Oh Connor! Oh Sophie! Oh Tupelo!
author: Bobbin W.

description:
Whether you're a Bird Watcher or Owner, Visitor or local Bay Area resident, these wild Cherry Headed Conures are a special part of San Francisco to experience. 

After sharing Telegraph Hill with my winged neighbors, The Flock*, over the last year, I feel I owe it to these acrobatic characters to share a bit of the joy that they bring to my daily life. Every morning and afternoon they fill the skies with a green flurry of wings. It's a cacophonous and cheerful sound that always makes me smile and wish that I understood their secret language. They even inspired us to get a telescope for a closer look at them perched on the Redwood tree outside the window. I really do miss Molly, my Senegal Parrot. However, The Flock is just the right amount of "pet" for me--close enough to watch and enjoy their silliness and chatter AND landlord approved! 
____________________________

Here's some basic facts:

Flock Behavior:
Whether they are playing, eating, or flying, everything they do is within the safety of The Flock or smaller sub-flock groups. Throughout the years, this local parrot group has been known to socialize with other species of birds, such as Parakeets (aka Budgies) and Blue Headed Conures. However, they have remained primarily 1 species: Cherry Headed Conures (also known as Red Masked Conures). The flock depends on safety within healthy numbers. If one of them is sick or injured, they will most likely abandon/hurt that member.

Preening: 
Birds' feathers need to be straightened from the base of the feather to the tip on a daily basis. They do this with their beaks. Preening is a social thing for parrots and often times when they partner up this is a bonding activity. For example: domesticated birds will often try to preen their owner's hair. (Molly used to lovingly do this to me.)

Feeding:
They use their hookbills, which is an identifying parrot trait, to pry open local nuts and berries. Yes, people have and do feed them store bought seeds, but their diet is not supported by this. Remember: These birds are wild. They can and will bite if provoked. (Trust me, parrot bites can HURT A LOT and I have the scars to prove it!)

Nesting and Babies:
The Flock nests in the neighboring Presidio Eucalyptus trees during the spring. Their young remain nestled in the trees for about 3-4 months before they fledge from the nest. You can spot a baby by its predominately green color. The Cherry Head feathers, that they are known for, don't fully develop for several years.

Origin: 
Cherry Heads are native to Southwestern Ecuador and Northwestern Peru. The Flock's origin in San Francisco and the many stories of how they came about have never been confirmed: a broken crate of parrots shipped in from South America, escaped pets, etc.
____________________________

When I first moved to Telegraph Hill, my boyfriend and I happened to run into our new neighbor Mark Bittner, the author of The Parrots of Telegraph Hill. I have to admit, I was tongue tied and could barely say a thing! I wanted to tell him how much I enjoyed the book and felt that I really got to know The Flock through his writing. I now feel a special connection to them, knowing about his experiences with them and their history. If you love these birds, you will love the book as well!

*Note: The facts I shared are both from Mark's book and from my own knowledge having been a bird owner.
author: Kira R.

description:
Awesome birds! They were in the trees at Drumm and Washington on my way home from work.

Would buy again.
author: Matthew B.

description: They make me giggle like a school girl with their incessant squeaky chattering. Neat little story about how they ended up in SF and it's always fun to spot them flying by. When you hear them, you can't help but wonder what they're going on about. They don't only hang out at Telegraph hill, in fact, there's a big group that hang out at Fort Mason.
author: Lily K.

description:
Seeing these birds for the first time is one of those only SF wonder experiences.

My first time was the end of a long evening of debauchery.  Decided to grab a coffee drive up to Coit Tower and watch the sunrise.  Just as the first rays began to streak across the hill a magnificent pandemonium of parrots erupted from the trees circling the tower and the hill a couple of times before streaking off into the sun.  The cacophony of their cries and wings was as startling as their colors and majesty.  

Hubby and I have also found them in the trees along the embarcadero from Levi's Plaza all the way down to Justin Herman Plaza.  We watched them playing tree to tree in the early dusk one evening in the park next to plaza.  

They are an SF treasure and every local should make the effort to see our parrots at least once.  We watch for them whenever on their turf.
author: Russell D.

description:
Love you guys!  The little cherry-headed conure parrots, that is.  I had to learn about you through your documentary and I fell in love even more.

Pay no attention to those calling you squawkers.  These are the same people that probably go to loud restaurants, go to concerts, get into fights drunk at bars and go clubbing.  Not that I wouldn't do those things, but your sounds are a part of you.

I love how you all coffee klatch behind 3 Embarcadero Center at the same tree around 7AM every morning.  Seeing & hearing you enjoy yourselves makes me want to get coffee too.  I look up to see you in the tree and I delight in joy when I can see you take flight.  My stopping and looking up at you draws attention to those walking and driving by.

The Parrots of Telegraph Hill are quintessential San Francisco - enjoy!
author: Janet H.

description: I didn't see any of the famous parrots but I did hear 'em! It's a pretty hard climb up to the top if you're not in shape but it's worth the walk!
author: Tom T.

description:
Love them! They are nice to look at, there is a cute movie about them, and they COMPLETELY mesmerize my dog when they fly over Washington Square park. Plus, it's true, what other cities can claim random wild parrots?

I never lived along the back of telegraph hill where the squawks get rather loud, instead when I resided in north beach (off grant and union) I welcomed the bird calls as they passed over our house to their favorite spot. Much nicer a sound than the drunk kids stumbling down from the Tivoli to vomit on my lightpost.

I miss them now that we've moved, there's a parrot living across the street from us in the castro who gives me the whistle while i take out the trash, but still, it's not the same.
author: Nikki M.

description:
SUCCESS!! 

May 22nd the S.F. Board voted 10-1 to ban feeding these parrots in any park in S.F. The birds will be healthier as they will now forage for their food the way nature intended and the many problems that were inherent in the feedings will come to an end or at least be minimized.

People will still be able to enjoy seeing the birds, but now they will see them as the creator meant them to be.

The supervisors are to be commended for their wisdom in giving the parrots the right to be wild birds and not pets. 

For further understanding as to why this action has been taken, please see article at: 

www.paws.org/wildlife/resources/fact_sheets/feedingwildli...
author: Michelle S.

description: I'll never forget the first time I saw the wild parrots. I was chaperoning a group of students on a field trip to Coit Tower and my students were milling about, enjoying the scenic view of San Francisco when we heard the oncoming shrieks of the wild parrots approaching. Overhead a small group of about five parrots circled the tower. I thought someone was playing a joke on us. I had no idea how so many parrots could possibly be flying free around San Francisco. They kept circling around the Tower about every 10 minutes or so, and just seeing the tropical birds seemed to make the temperature rise a few degrees every time they flew past.
author: Dani C.

description:
The Wild Parrots of San Francisco gather in the trees in the park at Clay and Drumm about an hour or more before dusk.  (Check weather report for Sunset time).   You can just watch, but if you want to feed them, bring either soft fruit (apples, grapes, etc) or nuts.  Sunflower seeds in the shell are best.  If you are bringing an apple, also bring some disposable chop sticks.  Put a slice of the apple on one end of the stick.  If you are bringing nuts, also bring an open container, like a pie plate or paper plate, to hold the nuts (seeds) available to the birds.  

After a few minutes, the parrots will notice what you have to offer, fly down and land on your arm or head.  You will be better prepared if you are wearing long sleeves and a hat.  Their feet are little sharp, but not painful.  They bite your ear if they feel that they aren't getting the food fast enough.  Again, it hurts a little, but not painful.  I have never seen anyone with a "soiled" garment, but it could happen.

Bring a camera if you want to document the experience and show the folks back home.  It is an "only in San Francisco" experience.  If you love animals, it is a great experience.
author: Bart V.

description:
My usual encounter with the parrots is actually during my run from Mission Dolores up through Alamo Square and on to Alta Plaza.  Sometimes around Alamo Square you can hear this terrific squawking, definitely not the usual twitter twitter of birds.  Then this cloud of parrots flies overhead.  Apparently they roost out near 24th and Dolores St in the palms.  I haven't had the patience yet to stalk them out there, I always happen to be there when they are out feeding.

I just ran into the other group on Telegraph hill today while showing the inlaws around town and up the Filbert steps.  Very sad to read the posting that some people are taking advantage of the fact that the parrots have become inured to people feeding them and that some of them, including the infamous Nathalie mentioned here, have been kidnapped by some folks.  Not sure how much is true, but if you love these parrots, you probably shouldn't be enabling their demise by feeding them and letting them think all humans are friendly.
author: Jean K.

description: Sadly, you are no longer allowed to feed the birds, because they were forgetting how to feed themselves. But they're still cute.
author: Fawn F.

description:
These birds were here before all y'all moved in.
Sheesh-what kind of Grinch could hate 'em anyway?
If you can afford rent on Telegraph Hill you can afford a car and a place far away in the suburbs.  
I love them beautiful, loud, and sociable.  As is SF.
Don't like 'em? Go back to where you're from!!!
author: j s.

description:
When they fly to Noe Valley for vittles during the summer months, it makes me smile.

I love parrots, and while I could never have such loud, boisterous conures as pets, I'm glad they have a nice toe-hold in the flora and fauna of San Francisco.

And to those who say they are detriment because they are non-native, I say pshaw, you're most likely not native either and we let you stay.
author: C P.

description: The movie is great and all but I guarantee if you spend a significant amount of time under the parrot flight pattern you will start to wish that they would just fall out of the sky. Those sumbitches make a noise worse than nails on a chalkboard. You might even dream of fire arms, despite being a pacifist who firmly believes in gun control.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
So I was parking my car at Fort Mason on Thursday, and low and behold, a winged mass flies towards me as I get out of the car.  I had to do a double take, because it appeared these birds were...green.

I rubbed my eyes, and refocused, but the green didn't go away.  The 20 or so parrots landed in a tree right next to me.  

It took me a few minutes to register what I was seeing.  Parrots!  The Parrots of Telegraph Hill.  At Fort Mason.  In a tree.  Next to my car.  Eating berries. 

Brilliant green birds with red heads.  It was beautiful and surreal.  Like a Dali painting or an acid trip.

I hung out and watched them for about 5 minutes.

Before I left I asked one of them if he wanted a cracker.  No answer, and goddamn it if he didn't roll his eyes at me.
author: Rachel G.

description:
Shut the Hell Up, Parrots of Telegraph Hill!!

I must agree with Gwynnie....they're cute from afar but even
the Birdman of Alcatraz would lose it with these bastards
vacationing in his neighborhood.

For the past three months two of the Telegraph Hill gang seemed
to be using the fire escapes in my 'hood as their personal jungle
gym.  Just recently, a third has joined the flock.   The noise is
almost deafening when they really get on a roll.  

I took a video of the original two in mid-squawk when a wee 
little black bird started swooping down on them until they finally 
took off.

It was great!  Go get 'em 'lil black bird!!

Even the other birds are saying:
"What the Fuck?" 
"I thought they OWNED Telegraph Hill."
"What the hell are they doing here?!"
"Christ... Do they *ever* shut up?"

It's easy to say...awwwww, but they're so cute.  Yeah that's true...
when you have the freedom to walk away!
author: K-leen F.

description:
Spending the night at my parents' house on Russian Hill is something I do more often than I'd like to admit. They have HBO. They have ESPN. They have food in their refrigerator. They even have a bed for me now that my brother is in college.

And some mornings, as I brush my teeth and look out the bathroom window at our neighbors' towering magnolia tree, I can even spy thirty or so parrots barely weighing on its sturdy limbs. Those beautiful, crazy birds never fail to put me in a great mood before work. 

When The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill learn how to dive bomb the Wild Frat Boys of North Beach, I'll bump them up to five stars. (I'm trying to teach them.)
author: Nicholas E.

description:
Awwww how precious...how charming...how...utterly annoying. 

Try working next to a flock of these things. Every time I walk to lunch, walk to work, sit at my desk, make phone calls, work on time intensive projects, etc. these little guys are running amok in the skies above my office and as much as you try to block them out, you find any effort to do so is futile. 

Sometimes I try to forget that they are around, and then they start swarming and squawking and making their presence known. It's a bit of a surreal experience because when they're fluttering above you while you're walking down the street, you always think that some morbid fate is going to befall you... as if some large winged harpie is going to rip you to shreds. It's unsettling really, but mostly ridiculously annoying.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
I often wondered what that obnoxious load screeching noise was...? It sounds as if a flock of birds are being tortured at the same time same place daily... At times I'd have to close the office window just to talk on the phone as the screech swarms by. 

BUT... to discover the noises are PARROTS! Parrots of Telegraph Hill, oooh how exciting... Now I cant wait to hear the screech... I peer out my window every day at about 1:00pm when they flock whips by. 

It makes me smile... And that my friend is priceless on a Monday afternoon!
author: Dee C.

description:
Long story short, I loved the movie! I thought it was amazing. So I went to the area and I gazed upon the beauty of the Parrots. They're fun! I like staring at birds and hoping they don't shit on my sweater.

... Then I realized. 'Yea, it would totally suck to have these peckers babbling all day and night when I'm trying to work or eat. Period!"
author: Andrew C.

description: Great film, great birds, and admirable human being. This makes San Francisco a cooler place to be, and it's already the coolest place ever.
author: Y K.

description: I saw the documentary and was fascinated and I did look for them while visiting San Fransisco but did not see them up close but  I heard them. Then suddenly  I saw then fly by  in a flock and the colors were amazing! Then they were gone! Believe it or not we do have wild parrots here in NYC in several neighborhoods and even tour buses to see them but they are a grayish green. The parrots in San Fransisco are colorful! If you are going to visit San Fransisco watch the documentary first and then look for them. There are guided tours but I thought I would just try to do it on my own. If I am fortunate enough to go to San Fransisco again I will take a guided tour so I can get some pictures.
author: Pinky And The B.

description:
Hokay, so.

Not only did I read the book about the parrots but I went and saw the documentary! As a North Beach resident I have become slightly obsessed with the birds. They are definitely one of the cool, unique fun facts about San Francisco that I like to tell visitors about. I love the fact the fact that no one really knows where they came from and also that the neighborhood and the city come together every few years to save them from some new threat. 

My advice for those who want to actually see the parrots, avoid trying to spot them around Telegraph Hill.  Go to Maritime Plaza near the Embarcadero Center during the day and you'll most likely see a large flock hanging out in the trees making all sorts of racket.
author: Derek B.

description:
Last night I watched the documentary on KQED and I CRIED. Hardcore, open mouth CRIED.

I'm such a pansy.
author: Jackie I.

description:
Saw them for the first time yesterday. Some wrote that they scare off native San Francisco birds... if that means PIGEONS... then I will welcome it.

I look forward to seeing the movie.
author: Brian P.

description: You can hear them from Coit tower, but you have to walk down the steps to actually see the Parrots. Such a cool and unique part of San Fran that everyone should experience. I mean, when do you get to see wild parrots in the middle of a city??
author: Alison H.

description: Ok it all makes sense to me now. I thought I had been hallucinating when I walked down Drumm street and saw all these little green dudes kicking it cold nine on top of the buildings. Now that I know that there's a movie about them I'm gonna have to go check that out.
author: Kim N.

description:
During 17 years of city living, I'd heard many legends about the Parrots of Telegraph Hill but never actually saw them. I thought they were a myth - that is until I saw the documentary about them (such an awesome movie!) I fell in love with them and hoped for the day I would actually see them in person (sort of stalker-ish sounding, I know). 
Then one day, as I was walking to the Ferry Building on my way home from work, I heard a familiar chattering sound from the sky. I looked up to see a flock of little green sprites flittering through the air. My heart raced a little bit and I think I gasped out loud. I felt like I had a celebrity sighting (sort of like the time I ran into J-Lo and Ben Affleck at Fred Seigel's in L.A., except way cooler and much more memorable).
author: Delilah P.

description:
They are so green and so pretty.  I saw them for the very first time near the Embarcadero...not believing my eyes.

When we moved to the area, we learned more about them.  My brother rented the movie for us and we've been on the hunt to look for them, as well as my nieces with no luck. 

The closest we've come to a flock of them, about 20-30, was when they flew above and landed on a tree near Green and Grant.  We would have missed them if not for their squawking.  It was a sunny and hot day but I was just so intrigued by them that I stood there in the scorching sun and watched.  Totally amused and counting while wishing my nieces were with me.  

Since that one encounter, we have come across them more regularly but still from a distance.  Everytime we see them fly by, I'll say hi.  Whenever I hear them squawk - the loudest early in the morning - I can't help but smile and think the parrots are having so much fun in that one big tree just blocks away.  It's a fantastic way to start a day.

Sorry for those who live too close to them and not enjoying it.  We live just a few blocks away, maybe just the perfect distance.
author: Gloria H.

description: It's pretty cool/crazy. You're walking through some gardens on your way to Coit Tower, and you hear this squawking, and you look up, and there are trees full of parrots! I'd seen the movie, but it was still so surprising and beautiful. I've seen flocks of parrots in Mexico, but seeing them right in SF was even better, made me proud of this city.
author: Syd S.

description:
I was here the last day that you can legally feed the birds (7/15), and it was quite fun..

Take away the fact that it may be bad for both feeder and feedee, and it was a fantastic experience.

Beautiful birds, landing all over you.. Luckily no poopage..
A wonderful, Wonderful, with a capital 'W', experience..


now, You can't do that.

I am happy that the law was put to best benifit for both human and bird in many ways.
We don't want to degrade the birds, and we don't want guests catching anything, that being  a disease or a bird itself..

But the other part of me misses it..
i mean, There's just a sort of instant bond not between bird and man, but guest and guest.
There's something about having random people plopped down into a situation, like having a flock of wild parrots around you, and then instantly being sort of connected being that you're all on the same page.
Laughing at where the birds land, and how many birds are on you, or sharing seeds..

There's not many situations as simple as this where many, random people of many kinds can have fun and bond...

-fast forward-

...What I'm trying to say is that it's still nice to see the birds, but it's even more immersive when you're involved.

Again, I am totally for protecting birds and silly humans, but it's an experience lost..

thus, Not gaining my 100% approval stamp..
author: Nicolo T.

description:
I work in the north waterfront area, and see the parrots every day. It's always a delight to be outside and have a flock of 20 or so suddenly fly by - man, are they loud.

To the people who feed them in Ferry Park each afternoon - STOP IT!  They do not need to eat the food you provide them, and can often become ill from contact with humans. Our germs are different from theirs, ya know?
author: .Hon H.

description:
Hypocracy. Days after the ordinance passed stating that it is no longer legal to feed the parrots, Mark Bittner was in the park shooing away the parrots I was feeding apples to (I hadn't heard about the ordinance yet). It is ignorant for him to think these birds were wild when he discoverred them and began feeding and caring for them- that's simply not possible.

I am a biologist and have raised many birds, including parrots over the years, and when he chastised me I was ready to clock him in the face. I can see if you are feeding them rice and crackers, that's not great, but I'm sorry, I just so happened to know what a parrot's diet is in nature, and they are CERTAINLY not going to find it in an urban city to suit their necessary intake.

Birds that live in a concrete city have NEVER been wild, Mark! They will NEVER know how to hunt and gather on their own and  an ordinance will not change that. Not to mention, shooing the birds away only causes distress to these creatures. Shame on you for prosperring from your "mission" to help these parrots.
author: Erin L.

description:
So my mother is an avid parrot lover, having one of her own, and was visiting the city. She saw the documentary and was ecstatic about seeing these birds. 

I had never seen them myself in person so I did some research on where to find them. Theres a couple spots they frequent, the filbert steps, around coit tower, and the parks near embarcadero. 

Following some reviews here, we went to the parks at Clay & Drumm just before sundown. They were in all the trees making a racket. I would suggest going there at least an hour before sundown and waiting if they're not there yet. After it gets dark its a little hard to see them in the trees, you can only make out what look like dark shadows.
author: Joshua G.

description:
i love these guys! how amazing is san francisco?

they also kick it in my backyard at the base of mount davidson, when the red tailed hawk isn't around.

reviewer gwynnie p. is such a grump! i'm sure her yappy little dogs make a racket much worse than the cute squawks of the parrots.
author: Elle C.

description:
They are super cute.  
They make a strange squawking sound, its fun to listen for.
I kinda miss them, no parrots in soma... some strange colorful sights and lotsa wild squawking day and night, but never as cute.
author: Today Y.

description:
I used to see "Lost Parrot" posters in my old hood (TenderNobbish). I had romantic fantasies about how the lonely birds had a secret agreement to join the flock and fly away to Telegraph Hill. I couldn't help adding a dash of Tom & Jerry to the story with a twist of a domineering cat bullying the poor wittle parrot in it's cage.

Since moving to the Jtown-ish area, I've discovered the flipside of this vision: a total balls out crew of raging parrots. The rag-tag ghetto gang that flies around my hood aren't the poshified birds of Telegraph Hill, these little buddies gang up and attack pigeons and crows, it's full blown bird-gang warfare. My cat cowers in terror at the cacaphony that ensues when they launch their attacks. cheee chee chEE CHEE! (Drive-by, duck and cover!)
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Definitely an interesting sight. Parrots. Not just your tiny parakeet on some guy's shoulder but I'm talking about the big green ones with some red. A huge flock that blends into the treeline. The squawking and berry seeds on the ground give them away though. 

It's nice to see something interesting on my way home these days.
author: Jason C. J.

description: If you haven't seen the movie "The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill" then you should be ashamed to call yourself a San Franciscan. These parrots are so adorable and it's so easy to personify them after watching that film. I was very pleased to spot them and to hear their cute, baby-like noises when wandering around whilst trying to distract myself from heartbreak. How can I be sad when poor Conor never found his lifelong mate and then fell prey to that damned hawk!? Some creatures have it so much worse!
author: Rachael S.

description:
Standing outside Mark (aka the Parrot Man)'s apartment obscured by immense foliage, deafened by the sound of countless colorful parrots as they flew overhead, I thought to myslef: "This is truly a San Francisco moment."

This city is full of characters, full of surprised, full of oddities that make this city especially charming and unique. By now, we all know about the parrots and what the story is (and if you don't, you MUST watch the documentary!)

But the fact that we are living amongst these parrots is pretty great. The other day I was hanging out at my friend's North Beach apartment outside, while a couple parrots swooped overhead. Probably on their way to Mark's...
author: Sophie D.

description:
SF is so awesome. I mean, how many cities in the US have their own flock of parrots?  I usually encounter the parrots at the park by Fort Mason across from the Safeway. In the summer I would walk down Van Ness and set up shop for sunbathing under the two palm trees in the middle.  Those little green love birds would fly in during the day and roost in the palm trees, squawking their little hearts out.  I'd be on the phone and the other person would be like, "I can't hear you! What is that noise?" and I'd say, "Oh, it's just the parrots."

The documentary was really fabulous too. A must-see for anyone who moves here.
author: Lisa R.

description: I live in Russian Hill, and see the birds flying just feet overhead on a daily basis.  Especially when I'm relaxing on the roof.  What a beautiful thing to have a tropical flavor added to the most beautiful city in the world - San Francisco.  The movie is a delight as well, well worth the 80 minutes.  And as noisy as they are, you get used to the noise quickly.  If anything, their noise is a soothing sound that let's me sleep more peacefully.
author: Cyrus S.

description: dont f*** with em cause they will f*** you up.! They are beautiful and  their main hangout is at the longshoremans hall. They chatter,  chirp,whistle, fly  from tree to tree.They be checkin YOU out too!..Its a parrots world...luv em from a distance... just too cute  make you wanna stretch out your hand so they can fly down get a pet....  or maybe not.....hey! I saw Alfred Hitchcocks the BIRDS!!! they even watching from the picture!
author: Jay E.

description: Met a gang of them atop Coit Tower. They were loud and swooping. I feared for a group fly by poop-shooting. Reminds me of the green parrots in Hollywood and Temple City. (They were imported for an exotic movie, then freed... now they live and breed and squawk).   -1 star for the fear factor and obnoxious way that they make themselves known.
author: Mindy L.

description: Noisier than a crowded, hot day in Shanghai. Cuter than a Furby  [and just as smart].  These little birdies are a don't miss.  Very special and entertaining! If you are ever in their neighborhood, look up up "Natalie" [a star senior of the flock, with multi-colored shoulder feathers] and "Edgar" [a clever newbie, with a spotted right wing]. Be sure to take along your Parrot food.  They will work for food, and they are especially crafty. And very green. And we all know ... it's not easy being green.
author: Elle L.

description: The famous parrots of the book and the movie..they are cherry headed conures, and they are soooo pretty and cute and fun to watch.  Nothing brightens my day more than when i happen upon them, chattering and frolicking in the trees near the embarcadero or in washington square park. they are a true san francisco treasure.
author: sarah C.

description: crap crap crap...kaw..kaw ...kaw...they are NOISY and poop a lot, but it is a wild san fran phenom..SF Board of Supes have implemented a fee fine for feeding wild parrots, and the guy that the movie was based around is the one supporting the notion of NOT feeding the parrots because he NOW states that they are wild and can survive off of what is available in san fran and they may become a bit tame with 5pm feedings around Embarcadero by the HUMAN pets..gee can't they just reduce the number of hired supes @ $150,000 a pop with all that they make they are just too huge a financial burden on a population base of ONLY 780,000. Gee whiz
author: miriam b.

description: I love these little guys! I just moved to SF 4 years ago with my Dog so I spend alot of time outside.  I also walk to Fort Mason park almost every day with my little furball so I have been raving about these birds for quite some time.  The first time I saw them I couldnt believe it.  Being from the midwest originally, I was frantic that they were a lost pet that got loose but the more and more I have visited Fort Mason I realized they are not a lost pet:)  I live in the North Beach/Russian Hill area so I hear them fly by almost every day.  Whenever I see them or hear them it brings a smile to my face.  It is funny because I have friends who have lived in SF for years and know nothing about them but to me that is kind of sad bc they must not take in or appreciate the beauty of SF enough.  You can sit on a blanket in a park with views of the Golden Gate Bridge, bay/ocean, big tanker ships coming in from whereever, sailboats, the Exploratorium, and last but not least look up and see parrots.  In my opinion it doesnt get any better than this.
author: nicole s.

description: I'm not sure if a movie actually belongs on yelp, but I am going for it. Before I saw this film the other night I never thought I could get so emotional about parrots named Connor, Sophie and other characters including a paraplegic parrot who is loved by the subject of the movie/aka bird caretaker. What a sweet film, if you live in SF (and even if you don't), see it!!
author: Nicole S.

description:
So special. It'd be commonplace if this were a Tropical climate. But here, where the fog rolls to thick that we don't see the blue sky for more than 1/2 the year I think its really amazing that we are home to these fluttering, squealing delights. 
Then again, I love when the Blue Angels practice before the big Fleet Week show too. For me, ain't nothin wrong with unforeseen flight patterns that are loud as hell. What I love about both the parrots and the F-16s is hearing them first and then trying to catch glimpses of them before they disappear. With that said I can see how, if the Blue Angels were around all the time I might not think it so special and I'd probably resent the constant noise, so I can see how some reviewers that live near the birds poo-poo them for the same reasons. However, I can't say that I could be upset if the parrots favored me with sightings everyday. They truly tickle me.
author: J C.

description: After taking some out of town guests for a cruise around the bay  I figured we were in the area so hence the trek up the Fibert Stairs along Telegraph Hill. The views are incredible, the gardens so lush it feels like you are literally taking a stairway to heaven. Although really you are climbing stairs to Coit Tower which is a huge fire hose shaped edifice. Wait, maybe it is the stairway to heaven. I digress. So about a third of the way up there is a cacophony of screeches as a flock of green parrots soar by and land in a large palm tree. We walk by and off they go. Ah, the parrots of Telegraph Hill. My spin...I guess there were a bunch of creepy needy people feeding the birds instead of the homeless at Glide. Soooo the city had to outlaw feeding the parrots. I guess mommy never bought them a dog. Just keep climbing toward the fire hose.
author: Theresa H.

description: These birds are so super cute. Yes, I am a person who actually says super cute. Bite me. I love being able to show family/friends this great little creatures when they are in town. It sounds dumb but it really is kind of a simple pleasure to watch these birds.
author: Anita B.

description:
After seeing the movie, hike Telegraph Hill. The views are fantastic both of the Bay, the multi-milion dollar homes and most of all, the gardens. 

You can go with the SF city guides on a free guided tour or go on your own. For some beautiful photos along the tour and detailed map of a suggested hike, please visit:

http://locomotoring.net/2009/06/13/birds-and-bees-of-telegraph-hill/ 

PS: The birds can also be seen as far as Fort Mason and along the gardens/trees near Embarcadero. In particular, the Sydney Walton park (http://locomotoring.net/2009/06/18/old-ship-saloon/).
author: Mishti D.

description: A flock of them live across the street from my apartment.  They wake me up when the sun rises, which right now is about 6am.  If I hadn't seen the movie I might get annoyed, but I love them.  Sometimes when they get real loud, I talk to them and say, "What are you guys yellin' about?!".  They don't hear me, but I really do wonder what is the big deal up in those trees so early in the morning.  Glad the parrots have found a safe haven here in SF.
author: e w.

description: These funny little birds entertain me outside my window, all day long. Occasionally, they swarm overhead like a technicolored Hitchcock remake, chirping and cackling and I can't help but laugh along with them.
author: Eric ..

description: It's wonderful watching this beautiful flock of birds. Sometimes they travel to the park on the backside of the Embarcaderos and it's a wonderful lunchtime  treat.
author: Valerie V.

description: I used to live in north beach close to tel hill...and these parrots are damn cute !  Minus 1 star for their incessant chirping
author: Francis K.

description: In the middle of the day, during the rustle & bustle of city life... our wild parrots squawk freely reminding us of the simple joys in life.
author: Clay K.

description: Note: these parrots become less wild the more we feed them.  They lost a star for all of the bird groupies who serve them buckets of seeds and apples every day.  They're fun to appreciate but trust me, they have plenty of available "wild" food.  Aside from that they're beautiful birds with fiery personalities, just watch your ears if they jump on your shoulders.
author: Michael P.

description: These birds are so great and one of the things that makes the city of San Francisco unique.  They can be found in various places around the city and at specific times.  It is always a joy for me to find them, I stop in my tracks and just watch.  The history of the parrots is also so unique and I think everyone that is interested in the birds should watch the documentary, "The Parrots of Telegraph Hill."  It's a bit boring, but full of information.  Very cool, definitely take time to watch them if you get a chance.
author: Meghana A.

description: Like the parrots, it's fun to see them in the city. Now that the city banned feeding them, which like most cities they should have, it seems like they are doing well.
author: David K.

description: I was recently stuck in traffic in the Presidio. Like, stuck behind a little league parade stuck.  It was getting a little bit warm so I rolled my window down to get some air.  I start to hear what sounds like little girls laughing...  cackling actually.  I look up and see my pals. the parrots.  They were being goofy as usual in the eucalyptus trees.  Yea for the birds.
author: hunny b.
